Award.AwardTitle: Small: Collaborative Research: Programmed Cyclic Molecular Dancing on 2D Origami Lattices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Molecular interactions can be seen as molecular communications and exchanges of information. In recent years the understanding of molecular information processing has been explored through DNA-based bottom-up self-assembly. These studies explore algorithmic, programmable molecular interactions including molecular devices. In this work, two PIs with complementary expertise, a chemist and a mathematician, join together to further the possibilities for programmed molecular interactions. The goal of this highly interdisciplinary project is to introduce environmental control within the DNA self-assembly process that will direct molecular interactions in a preprogrammed manner. It introduces a "clock" (an essential part of computation) that controls programmed oscillating attachments/detachments of different molecular species on a predesigned platform. The proposed project will enable self-assembly of a variety of preprogrammed molecular shapes from the same set of building blocks. These shapes could serve as scaffolds for nanoelectronic components, which if achieved, will allow for smaller, denser and faster computer hardware. Furthermore, programmed dynamical molecular interactions would be the first incarnation of nucleic acid robots (nubots) acting on a platform. Several undergraduates and at least two PhD graduate students (one in each institution) will receive training through this award. This project will prepare these individuals as unique interdisciplinary research scientists able to pursue studies that require broad scientific knowledge.

The goal of this project is to introduce environmental control for periodic dynamical, molecular arrangements in molecular programming, to develop a method for molecular signal communication between different molecular species, and to use this method to obtain molecular arrangements that cycle in time. In particular the project will (1) develop molecular conditions for environmental control through laser illumination that will allow oscillating platform attachments/detachments between two different molecular floating tile species and (2) introduce algorithmic molecular interactions with oscillating dynamics between two molecular species by simulating a two-dimensional Game-of-Life-like dynamics on a two dimensional DNA origami array. The system has a platform consisting of a 2D DNA origami array whose tiles have signaling strands, and free floating tiles able to attach to their respective "identity" counterparts on the platform and to transmit signals to neighboring locations. The array tiles are arranged in a checker-board fashion such that in an alternate manner, at each cycle, one of the colors receives the floating tiles and computes the identity of the next cycle tiles of the other color tiles. The floating tiles are equipped with nano-particles whose exposure to appropriate laser wave length increases the local temperature and thereby can disassociate those floating tiles from the platform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this project, an interdisciplinary team consisting of experimentalists and theoreticians introduced the first environmental control for cyclic, dynamical, molecular arrangements in molecular programming. This is the first attempt to introduce a ``clock’’ type of control in the dynamics of molecular organization. Although we expected molecular conditions for environmental control through laser illumination, we discovered that illuminating molecules equipped with IR dyes would heat the entire solution. Instead, we developed a method that uses DNA triplex-forming-oligonucleotides (TFOs), which are DNA constructs that form a helix with three strands instead of the regular DNA double helix.  The binding to larger constructs could be controlled by pH. Although binding of regular duplex DNA is thought to be stronger than triplex DNA binding, we were able to find a sweet spot where TFOs could displace duplex strands when pH is reduced. We demonstrated the environmental control through a system of DNA-origami tiles that were able to simulate selection control of molecular species through oscillating changes in pH.  We showed theoretically that the method can be used to dynamically emulate the game-of-life by alternating attachments of two types (species) of floating molecular (DNA based) tiles on a predesigned array. The array can play the role of a platform that consists of communicating neighboring DNA tiles complementary to the floating tiles. We proved that for a platform with square tiles, only the checkerboard arrangement of the two species can provide communication between any two tiles of the plane. On the other hand, there are an uncountable number of arrangements of two types of hexagonal tiles on the plane which provide communication between any two tiles.

 

In our studies of how to control binding of DNA, we also learned how to add TFOs to self-assembled DNA crystals. We learned how to improve DNA crystals, in terms of order, by modifying the ends of the motifs forming them (the parts holding the crystals together). We also learned how to stabilize the crystals in non-aqueous environments, thereby leading to their possible use as scaffolds for nanoelectronics, whose molecular components are typically insoluble in water. We developed a method that can change the color of self-assembled crystals while the crystals are intact, and have learned how to place nanoelectronic components on a DNA origami to build a DNA Origami Based Molecular Electro-Optical Modulator.

 

Throughout the project 10 undergraduates and 2 graduate students were trained at NYU and one Masters and one PhD were awarded at USF.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2019
Modified by: Nadrian C Seeman
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: With this project, an interdisciplinary team consisting of experimentalists and theoreticians introduced the first environmental control for cyclic, dynamical, molecular arrangements in molecular programming. This is the first attempt to introduce a ``clock?? type of control in the dynamics of molecular organization. Although we expected molecular conditions for environmental control through laser illumination, we discovered that illuminating molecules equipped with IR dyes would heat the entire solution. Instead, we developed a method that uses DNA triplex-forming-oligonucleotides (TFOs), which are DNA constructs that form a helix with three strands instead of the regular DNA double helix. The binding to larger constructs could be controlled by pH. Although binding of regular duplex DNA is thought to be stronger than triplex DNA binding, we were able to find a sweet spot where TFOs could displace duplex strands when pH is reduced. We demonstrated the environmental control through a system of DNA-origami tiles that were able to simulate selection control of molecular species through oscillating changes in pH. We showed theoretically that the method can be used to dynamically emulate the game-of-life by alternating attachments of two types (species) of floating molecular (DNA based) tiles on a predesigned array. The array can play the role of a platform that consists of communicating neighboring DNA tiles complementary to the floating tiles. We proved that for a platform with square tiles, only the checkerboard arrangement of the two species can provide communication between any two tiles of the plane. On the other hand, there are an uncountable number of arrangements of two types of hexagonal tiles on the plane which provide communication between any two tiles. In our studies of how to control binding of DNA, we also learned how to add TFOs to self-assembled DNA crystals. We learned how to improve DNA crystals, in terms of order, by modifying the ends of the motifs forming them (the parts holding the crystals together). We also learned how to stabilize the crystals in non-aqueous environments, thereby leading to their possible use as scaffolds for nanoelectronics, whose molecular components are typically insoluble in water. We developed a method that can change the color of self-assembled crystals while the crystals are intact, and have learned how to place nanoelectronic components on a DNA origami to build a DNA Origami Based Molecular Electro-Optical Modulator. Throughout the project 10 undergraduates and 2 graduate students were trained at NYU and one Masters and one PhD were awarded at USF. Last Modified: 10/30/2019 Submitted by: Nadrian C Seeman
